Award.AwardTitle: Continuous Games in the Laboratory--Programming Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This award funds the involvement of undergraduates in the research already funded by NSF through award 0925039. The undergraduates will be working to develop parts of an innovative software platform that will be used to conduct experimental research in strategic decision making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supplemented grant SES-0925039, "Continuous Games in the Laboratory," for PI Daniel Friedman and co-PI Ryan Oprea.

As explained in the reports for that grant, this supplement enabled the hiring of a number of undergraduate programmers*, most of them Computer Science majors, to write, test and document software for conducting laboratory experiments in continuous time. The software is now being used at at least six labs around the world, and is being considered at perhaps a dozen additional labs. The software has already enabled research reported in 4 published papers and another 4 under review at major economics and game theory journals.

As explained in the reports for the main grant, the research enabled by the software (called ConG, for Continuous Games) gives new insights into strategic interaction among individuals and populatlions of individuals, with applications in Political Science as well as Economics. The borader impacts of the software and the research it enables may include better policy recommendations in anti-trust and other traditional areas. The broader impact of training undergraduate programmers includes better high-tech job placement for young US citizens.

 

*The progammers supported under this supplement include Joseph Allington, Pranava Adduri, Ashley Chard, Michael Cusack, Keith Henwood, Anthony Lim, Alex (Richard) Lou, Vadim Maximov, Jacob Meryett, Laker Sparks,
and Sam Wolpert. Most of them are now either working for Silicon Valley firms or in graduate school.
